Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: They are approached by a member facing a difficult life choice and need to give thoughtful guidance.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone pressed to my ear, listening to my brother’s shaky voice as he tried to process the news of his job loss. He needed me—just me, his sibling—to listen, to reassure him, to be present in his pain without judgment or advice. My heart ached for him, and I wanted nothing more than to drop everything and drive to his apartment, to sit with him in silence if that’s what he needed. But as I hung up, my phone buzzed again. It was a member of my congregation, desperate for guidance about a life-altering decision. As their pastor, I was expected to offer wisdom, to be calm and composed, to set aside my own turmoil and focus on their spiritual needs. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My brother needed my undivided love; my parishioner needed my undivided attention. I stared at my phone, heart pounding, caught between the pull of family and the call of my vocation, unsure which part of myself to answer first.
